title: FirstFT: Biden imposes sanctions on Russia for Ukraine ‘invasion'
text:
Joe Biden announced sanctions against Russia and warned that Washington was prepared to take further action as he accused Vladimir Putin of beginning an “invasion” of Ukraine.

The US president revealed measures yesterday targeting two of Russia's largest financial institutions, VEB and Promsvyazbank, which support economic development and defence projects, as well as the country's elites and their family members. Sanctions would be aimed at Russia's sovereign debt and preventing Moscow from accessing US capital and financial markets, said Biden.

Despite the tougher than expected measures, Putin has endorsed Russian-backed separatists' claims to the entire Donbas region of eastern Ukraine, taking the countries closer to full-blown conflict.

The move came hours after Germany's chancellor Olaf Scholz halted approval of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which connects Russia directly with Germany, scuppering Europe's most contentious energy project.

FT.com has the latest news on the Ukraine conflict.

  • Economy: Sanctions and high energy prices test global resilience against Ukraine crisis.

  • Opinion: Mali's use of Russian mercenaries complicates an already dangerous situation, writes our editorial board.

  • Explainer: What are Putin's options after recognising the breakaway region? Kyiv has few ways to respond beyond bolstering its defences.

  • Interview: Ukraine must be allowed to retain the option of Nato membership, Finland's foreign minister said.

  • Markets: The US S&P 500 index dropped into a correction while oil prices neared $100 a barrel yesterday. Boris Johnson wants to shut out capital-seeking Russian companies, but only three have listed in the UK since 2014.

  • Opinion: Russia's president sent troops across the border on the basis of a farcical myth of enforced unity, writes Timothy Snyder. Kathrin Hille argues that Asian allies fear the Biden administration will be distracted from its newly minted Indo-Pacific strategy.

Thanks for reading FirstFT Americas. What questions do you have about the crisis in Ukraine? Share them with us at firstft@ft.com — Wai Kwen

Five more stories in the news

1. Political and economic risks threaten Colombia's recovery from pandemic Colombia has recovered impressively from a sharp downturn that fuelled violent unrest last year but Latin America's fourth-largest economy is still not robust enough to cope with tougher challenges ahead, economists have warned.

2. US gas industry pursues ‘responsibly sourced' label to market their fuel to concerned consumers ExxonMobil, EQT and Chesapeake Energy are among the companies supplying gas certified as such by third parties, which say that they monitor for methane leaks and other forms of ecological damage. Demand for certification is booming, but critics have raised doubts.

3. Rio Tinto to pay $7.7bn final dividend as earnings soar Since the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, the mining sector has emerged as the dividend-paying powerhouse of the London stock market, returning huge sums of cash from record raw material prices.

4. Traders shun US penny stocks Trading in unlisted US shares has dropped almost three-quarters from its peak at the height of last year's retail trading frenzy, as investors rein in speculative bets and regulators crack down on potential fraud in penny stocks.

5. India's IT sector grapples with hiring ‘crisis' The India chief executive of software giant Salesforce said the country's IT sector was suffering a skills shortage “crisis” as companies struggled to meet surging demand and compete with well-funded tech start-ups for workers.

Coronavirus digest

  • Years of progress in fighting infectious diseases in the world's poorer nations have been wiped out after resources were redirected to tackle the Covid-19 pandemic and treatment disrupted, experts have warned.

  • Opinion: A mass return to the workplace brings a much-misunderstood area of risk to all careers: the work social event.

  • Employers warned they will be flying blind from tomorrow when all restrictions in England end as the government has not issued workplace safety guidance.

  • InterContinental Hotels Group, the owner of the Holiday Inn and Crowne Plaza chains, said business was “closer to pre-pandemic levels” in 2021.

  • Hong Kong announced yesterday that all residents would have to undergo mandatory Covid testing from next month.

Corporate earnings Barclays publishes its full-year results. Companies due to report include Petrobras, Danone, Heathrow airport, Metro Bank, Rio Tinto, Aston Martin Lagonda and eBay.

António Costa takes office Portugal's prime minister assumes his post after winning a snap general election.

What else we're reading and listening to

The monetarist dog is having its day Economists are being forced to relearn lessons about the importance of money supply. When people are holding more money than they desire, they want to get rid of it. This would lower the price of most assets, but the nominal price of money is fixed: a dollar is a dollar. The adjustment comes via higher prices for everything else — or inflation, writes Martin Wolf.

Star wars: why Nasa objects to Elon Musk's space race The US space agency warns over the impact of SpaceX's plan to launch 30,000 more satellites into orbit for its space-based broadband service. Nasa says more satellites would make it harder to detect a “potentially catastrophic” asteroid strike on earth.

Silicon Valley has learnt little from Elizabeth Holmes While the Theranos founder awaits sentencing over defrauding investors, venture capital money continues to flow into wild start-up ideas. No broader reckoning has taken place. Instead of triggering tougher due diligence, the tech sector is dismissing the case as an outlier, writes Elaine Moore.

Real-world profits in the metaverse Retailers such as Forever 21, Nike and Chipotle are creating virtual world stores in a bet it can boost profits. But is it a gimmick, or will the metaverse allow for the creation of low-overhead, high-margin ecommerce businesses that will transform global retail?

Why does my boss write such rude emails? In the latest episode of the Working It podcast, host Isabel Berwick speaks to Erica Dhawan, an expert on digital communication, about good email etiquette and Zoom hygiene. One question they tackle is whether or not it is rude to put a period on the end of texts, emails and DMs.

Gardens

Do you keep a gardening diary? It is one of those good intentions which seldom translate into reality. A look at Robert Darwin's garden diary brings us closer to the Victorians — and to the formative years of a boy who would go on to change the world.
